publicationStmt.p: File created by Evolving Hands project, Newcastle University

div.ab:
Recd
Received
August 23rd 1921
Wed. July 20 .
1921
Dearest Father . Ich fange an - really these days are so packed with
incident that I must quickly record them before one impression overlays
another. You must set them in an atmosphere which has been uninterruptedly
at a maximum of over 120 for the last three weeks. We had a rather
worse bout in 1917 but it only lasted a fortnight. I may mention that
for the first time in my life I've got prickly heat - not very bad
however. Well - on Monday the Jewish community gave a great
reception to Faisal in the grand Rabbi's official house. The
Garbetts + I represented
the Residency Refers to the British Residency in Baghdad, the home of British Administration within the region.
+ Mr Cornwallis came with the
Amir . The function took place at 7.30 a.m. in the big courtyard
of the house - you know the kind of place, a square court round which
the two storeyed house stands. It was filled with rows of seats, with
rows of notables setting in them, the Jewish Rabbis in their turbans
of twisted shawls, the leading Christians, all the Arab minsters +
practically all the leading Moslems, with a sprinkling of white robed,
black cloaked 'ulama. The court was roofed over with an awning,
the gallery hung with flags + streamers of the Arab colours. The
Jewish school children filled it + the women looked out from the
upper windows, + even from the roof they peered down from under
the awning. They put me on the right hand of the chair prepared
for Faisal - you know the absurd fuss they make about me,
bless them. Faisal was clapped to the echo when we came +
we all sat down to a programme of 13 speeches + songs
interspersed with iced lemonade, coffee, tea + cakes + ices!
It took 2 hours by the clock, in sweltering heat - one gets
accustomed to it, but still it is so. The most interesting speeches
were those of the Jews (Moslems spoke too). The Rabbi is too
old, luckily, to say anything, but he is a wonderful figure, stepped
straight out of a picture by Gentile Bellini . The speeches on
these occasions are all set speeches - the orators read them
off + they give you very little sense of reality, being entirely detached
from anything that is actually happening. Also, being composed in
the study + with down, the speaker is never curtailed by
forgetting what he intended to say, + he spares you nothing.
But yet they were interesting, because one knew the tension

which underlay them, the anxiety of the Jews lest an Arab
Govt Government
should mean chaos + their gradual reassurance, by reason of
Faisal 's obviously enlightened attitude + our obvious support of
him. Presently they brought the
Rolls of the Law This refers to Torah, signifying the first five books of the Hebrew Bible (Old Testament), also called the Law (or the Pentateuch, in Christianity)
in three gold
cylinders which were kissed by the Grand Rabbi + then by
Faisal, + they presented him with a small gold facsimile
of the tables of the Law + a beautifully bound Talmud. I
whispered to him that I hoped he would make a speech. He
said he hadn't meant to say much but he thought he
must, + added: "You know I don't speak like they do - I
just say what is in my thoughts." Towards the end he got up
+ spoke really beautifully; it was straight + good +
eloquent. I enclose the translation I made from the report in
the vernacular papers which was pretty accurate. He
made an immense impression. The Jews were delighted at
his insistence on their being of one race with the Arabs, + all
our friends - the place was full of them - were equally
delighted with his allusion to British support. But I hear
that the more fanatical Moslems, especially the
Shi'ahs An Islamic sect who believe that the descendants of the Prophet Muhammad are the rightful leaders of Islam.
, have
been complaining a little that he takes Jews + Christians too
much on an equality with Moslems + the wild extremists
complain of any allusion to help from us.
The
villain vilain
of the piece is Saiyid Muhammad Sadr , the son
of old Saiyid Hasan Sadr whom I took you to see in
Kadhimain. Saiyid Muhammad was the man who first
received us, a tall, black- bearded
'alim An Islamic legal scholar.
with a sinister
expression. At the time you + I paid one call, Saiyid
Muhammad was little more than the son of Saiyid
Hasan, but a month later he leapt into an evil prominence
as the chief agitator in
the disturbances The revolt against British rule that began in May 1920 with the onset of mass meetings and demonstrations in Baghdad, also referred to as the 1920 Arab Revolt. The revolt ended in October 1920.
. In those insane
days he was treated like a divinity. Shi'ahs kissed the robe
of men who had touched his hand. We tried to arrest him
early in August + failed. He escaped from Baghdad +
moved about the country like a flame of war, rousing the

2
tribes. It was he who called up the Diyalah tribesmen +
caused all those tragedies of which Mrs Buchanan 's story is
one. His next achievement was on the upper Tigris . In
obedience to his preaching the tribes attacked Samarra
but were beaten off. He then moved down to Karbala
+ was the soul of the insurgence on the middle Euphrates .
Finally, when the game was up, he fled with other
saiyids Muslim honorary title
+ tribal
shaikhs Honorific title meaning 'Elder', used for leaders of tribes and royal family members.
across the desert to Mecca + came
back, under the amnesty, with Faisal . He is tended to be
second to Faisal, if indeed Faisal were not second to him,
but Faisal can't bear him + he finds himself
relegated relagated
to a position of comparative obscurity, with us, whom
he hates, + our friends, whom he hates equally, occupying
the front of the stage. He has still a certain amount of
influence + it's a hand to hand conflict between us
+ him. We have won the first round. It was he who
drafted the unofficial formula of allegiance, of which
I told you last week; Faisal has forbidden its circulation
+ we have issued an official formula through the
Ministry of the Interior . Everyone is signing ours. He
is in a black rage + I feel as it we were struggling
against the powers of evil in the dark. You never know what
Shi'ahs An Islamic sect who believe that the descendants of the Prophet Muhammad are the rightful leaders of Islam.
are up to. But we are
winning. I've scored a minor triumph over him - I
expect he knows it. The editor of one of the vernacular
papers announced that he intended to publish are
illustrated volume of biographies of the leaders of the
Iraq revolt The revolt against British rule that began in May 1920 with the onset of mass meetings and demonstrations in Baghdad, also referred to as the 1920 Arab Revolt. The revolt ended in October 1920.
. I sent for the editor + pointed out to
him that the moment was not propitious - the object
of all should be to blot out the events of the year
1920 as though they had never been. Since he knew
well that, I could close down his paper tomorrow, the

editor bowed to my arguments, + the projected book
is still-born.
Father , isn't it wonderfully interesting to be watching
over the fortunes of this new state ! But it takes
one all one's time. There are so many quicksands.
Since his return, I hadn't seen Muhammad Sadr
till today. This evening there was a great function to celebrate
the opening of the Officers' School, our
Sandhurst for the
Arab Army. I arrived rather late + the first person I saw
was Saiyid Muhammad sitting by Sir Percy in the seats
reserved for great personages. He looked like Lucifer +
scowled at me as I gave him the salute. I sat down
two places away + after passing the time of day with
my neighbour, a rather colourless
'alim A scholar of Islamic law.
, I asked
tenderly after the health of his father, Saiyid Hasan ,
+ said you frequently enquired about him! I expect
that made Saiyid Muhammad furious - that anyone
should think of Saiyid Hasan + not of himself; but
since he was his father he couldn't do anything
but send you heaps of
salams Arabic word meaning 'peace'\u003b also used as a form of greeting.
! Faisal then
arrived + was installed between Sir Percy +
Mr Cornwallis . There was an opening speech by the
dear little Arab officer who is at the head of
the school, Ahmad Haqqi , + then a couple of
poems about the splendour of military service,
followed by an excellent speech by Ja'far
ending in enthusiastic gratitude to Sir Aylmer for
the help he had given the Arab army. After
which Sir Aylmer made a charming little speech
- he is playing the game like a man - +
Ja'far translated it into Arabic. No one paid the

3
slightest attention to Muhammad Sadr who sat
there scowling. He was left behind, bathed in scowls, + I
saw him no more, when Faisal accompanied, by the
officers of the school, British + Arab, Sir Percy , Sir
Aylmer + the rest of us, walked round + inspected
the premises, Faisal with his great charm + his
evident pleasure in it all making the centre of the
picture.
I think we are going to beat Muhammad Sadr + all
the other devils, but as I said before, it takes one
all one's time.
We had 30 Nasiriyah shaikhs in yesterday + they
have all gone back to sign the official declaration
of allegiance presented to them by their local authorities.
Many of them confided to me that they had refused
to sign the unofficial one here, + I clapped them
on the back, metaphorically. They were followed
by 15 of the tribal shaikhs +
saiyids Muslim honorary title
who led the
revolt The revolt against British rule that began in May 1920 with the onset of mass meetings and demonstrations in Baghdad, also referred to as the 1920 Arab Revolt. The revolt ended in October 1920.
. They all went up to see Sir Percy who
gave them, I've no doubt, excellent advice, for they
all came back + fell on my neck. Saiyid Nur
who is the most influential tribal saiyid on the
middle Euphrates + an old friend of mine, stayed
for half an hour explaining to me how it had
all happened. It was rather a muddled explanation
but I didn't appuyer much, partly because I
was
distractling distracted
occupied with the irrelevant
thought that Saiyid Nur is the walking image
of Noah out of Noah's ark. It was towards
the end of a long hot morning + I think I must have

been getting rather light headed. Still, he is.
This morning, before going into office. I took Mr Cornwallis
to see Shukri Alusi , the famous
Sunni An Islamic sect who do not believe that the descendents of the Prophet Muhammad are the rightful leaders of Islam.
'Alim Muslim learned in religious matters.
of Baghdad ,
of whom I have often told you. He is a
Wahhabi A member of a strictly conservative Muslim sect founded in the 18th century with the aim of eliminating all innovations later than the 3rd century of Islam.
+ has a romantic attachment to Ibn Sa'ud . He
hadn't been to see Faisal + he is not naturally
inclined towards him, but he stands so deservedly
high in public estimation that he had to be drawn in.
After, if I may say so, a very skilful 3/4 of an
hour of conversation conducted by Mr C. + me -
during which Mr. C. fell a complete victim to
my dear Shukri Effendi - the latter accepted with
enthusiasm an invitation to to go + have a talk with
Faisal. One gets a great deal of pleasure
out of little episodes of this kind.
Sunday July 24 . On Thursday morning we had rather a scare. News
had been coming in that Saiyid Mhd Sadr had sworn over
all the tribal
Saiyids Muslim honorary title.
, Saiyid Nur + the rest, not to sign the
official formula of allegiance. Most of the shaikhs, it was said,
had refused to swear to Mhd Sadr's scheme, but the tribal
saiyids had been packed off to get a Fatwah, an order, from
the
Shi'ah An Islamic sect who believe that the descendants of the Prophet Muhammad are the rightful leaders of Islam.
divines of Najaf . Sir Percy , Mr Garbett + I
went into consultation over this + Mr G. went round to see
Faisal. However Faisal was confident these was nothing
in it + later news seems to show he was right. He sent
for me that afternoon + we had a long talk. He is positive
that Mhd Sadr is losing ground daily + that as long as we
+ he stand firmly together we shall easily win through. He had
been somewhat ruffled by a stupid little incident. He had told
the Nasiriyah shaikhs, who came up in deputation to see him,
to swear personal fealty to him as all the other shaikhs
had done. Their
Mutasarrif Governor of an administrative district.
had consulted Sir Percy who replied

4 that that was between them + Faisal - it didn't concern him.
This answer the Mutasarrif , who is not very bright, had taken
to mean that Sir Percy didn't wish it, so he told the shaikhs
that they must only sign the official declaration of allegiance
+ told Faisal that the shaikhs had scattered + he could
not get hold of them. Faisal was hurt + angry + explained
to me at great length that from the Moslem point of view.
only the personal oath, with your hands between the hands of your
lord, counts for your personal fealty. "If they imagine they
don't owe personal allegiance to me" he said "I shall never be
able to rule this country." In fact he was a little jealous of
Sir Percy's supposed wish having overruled his order. I told
him that in fact the present position was that the people
were taking him from us, knowing that he had Sir Percy's
approval + support, but that our hope + expectation was
that when he was established as king he would make his
own place, independently of us, keeping us as his friends +
helpers. I think he was comforted but we shall have to get
the Nasiriyah shaikhs up again to swear to him. I asked
him about his wife , who is his cousin, + his children -
he has 3 - + said I thought she too ought to be encouraged
to make a position + a court. He was rather shy about
her - they always are embarrassed about their women,
thinking that they are too ignorant to be presentable, but he
agreed that we must make a beginning + I hope when she
comes I shall be able to get her to play a little part - have
the native ladies to see her + be treated like a queen.
It will be interesting to see what can be done. Faisal looked
terribly
very hot + tired; he had been talking to shaikhs
+ people all day; Mr Cornwallis is away in Mosul
+ he had had no one else to consort with. It's a terrible
labour becoming a king!

I went on to the Civil Hospital to see a shaikh of the
'Anizah Arabian tribe of Upper Mesopotamia and the Levant area.
whose romantic story is as follows: he was camped in the
middle of the Syrian desert when suddenly his encampment
was attacked by a famous old raider from the Syrian
frontier, Audah Abu Tai . After a stiff fight they beat
Audah off though he looted a great many camels. Shaikh
Murdhi was carried back wounded to his tents. Thereupon
appeared the British convoy of motors who were
returning from Ramadi to 'Amman whence they
had come - the pioneer journey across the desert.
With them was one of our Political Officers from
Ramadi + he knew Murdhi well. He bound up his
wound + told him he would send help. At the
next stage the motors fell in with a covey of
aeroplanes coming over from Amman + charged
them to pick up Murdhi + bring him in to
hospital at Baghdad . They wirelessed the news
here, an ambulance was ready at the aerodrome,
he went straight to hospital + is now up + about.
Rather a wonderful advertisement for our aeroplanes,
isn't it! but it will take them all their time if they
intend to play the Good Samaritan to the whole desert.
There is a very nice + interesting man here, Mr Barrington
Ward, a barrister + Lionel Smith 's brother in law. He
has come out to defend a wealthy Jew called
Sha'shu' who is being tried for murder. Mr B. W. can't
defend him in the courts because he doesn't belong to
the Iraq bar, but he posts Sha'shu''s counsel. The
murder has created a great stir. The victim was a
Christian, husband of an extremely notorious woman who

5
was living with Sha'shu' + had lived with a good
many people before, including Saiyid Talib . There isn't
a scrap of evidence to show, that Sha'shu' had instigated
it except the presumption that he wanted to get rid of
the superfluous husband, + even that isn't correct for
it was the lady he was trying to get rid of. The really
interesting part is that Mr B. W. is convinced that the
instigator was Saiyid Talib, but fears it can't be proved.
Talib coveted, not Sha'shu''s mistress, but his very beautiful
house which he had already tried to get from him.
Sha'shu' vows (+ Mr B. W. believes him) that directly after
the murder Talib said he would get him off if he
gave him a very large sum of money. I'm afraid it will
rest at that, though it would mean a great deal to us
if Talib could never come back to this country - + a
great deal to the country. He is such a savage
villain vilain
that anything can be true of him. What company I took
you into, didn't I!
During this fearfully hot weather the only possible
exercise excercise
has been swimming. Every night we're free
4 or 5 of the young men in the office + I take the office
launch, go up above the town where there's a deep pool
+ willows on the bank among which I can undress. It's
most heavenly; we get in refreshed + hungry towards 8
o'clock. And every Sunday a big party of us go down
river in a steamer of Mr Tod 's, bathe + dine on the
steamer as we come back. Today the
temp. temperature
has
mercifully dropped, I should think 10 degrees. Mr
Tod + I rode to Haji Naji before breakfast. I
hope this adorable north wind will hold for
tomorrow Fakhri Jamil + I are motoring to Ramadi ,

guests of the Mutasarrif , to see a great gathering
of tribal standards + shaikhs, all the
'Anizah Tribe in Upper Mesopotamia and the Levant area.
+
Dulaim Largest Sunni tribe in Iraq\u003b dates to pre-Islamic era.
, in honour of Faisal . He's going too.
It ought to be wonderful.
I've got your letter of June 23. Oh I do sympathise
about Mrs Rosita Forbes ! Sir Percy + I are wondering
what we shall do when she proposes to come out here.
We saw her in Cairo , I must tell you. I haven't
yet got the
Palestine letter The Balfour Declaration was a statement made in November 1917 by British foreign secretary Arthur James Balfour. It declared Britain’s support for “the establishment in Palestine of a national home for the Jewish people."
you promise me + I'm
very anxiously awaiting it. I feel sure things
are going badly there. They are on the wrong road.
You are never to repeat - because officially I may
not hold these opinions - that from the very
beginning I've felt certain that if ever we succeed
in getting up an orderly Arab independent
kingdom here we shall drive both the French
+ the Zionists into the Mediterranean. Of course
they will all want to come in with us. And
it will happen.
Ever dearest your very affectionate
daughter
Gertrude.

Sir Hugh Bell Bart C B
Rounton Grange
Northallerton
England
ARAB BUREAU,
BAGHDAD
.
G L Bell
